commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Head into?  (3)
2. Noted doomsday prepper  (4)
3. Flash point?  (3)(6)
4. When squirrels may thermoregulate by splooting (4)(4)
5. Apt name for a narcissist?  (4)


RAM
NOAH
AHA MOMENT
HEAT WAVE
MIMI
Nice one for a Monday!
Cute crossword crux!
My work weeks are always easier to start when I get a sub 9min ;-)
My favorite little detail is that *only* the themed across answers contain Cs.

This was so easy, I didn't even notice a theme. 

It was as Monday as a Monday puzzle can get.
While a compadre is very very often an amigo, it doesn't mean that. Your compadre is the godfather of your child, comadre for women. It pretty much means your "co-parent"

I'll admit it.

I had a scary number of unfilled squares in the SW, and I ran through the unresolved clues several times before I finally figured out COWER.

EASYTIGER seems easy in retrospect, but I couldn't find it without a lot of crosses.

I honestly don't recall every hearing of INDRA, so that was a challenge.

And it wasn't until I got COWER that I got ROARS.  (I mean honestly, crowds do a lot of things:  Oles, Rahs, Gos, Boos, but none of them fit.

In short, not a good solve time for a Monday for me.
I don‚Äôt think there is even a chief Hindu god.

Sailors seas the day.

(It's a boat time I posted that.)

Thought I'd seize the day and tell you that I feel very KEEN about being on the OPENSEAS--and this puzzle is no exception!  Cute, classy crossword!

I have no rEGRETS about it except that if I gave it the letter grade it deserves, it wouldn't match the theme and that would be unKIND. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

C y'all later!

‚ÄúCity of Honolulu‚Äôs island‚Äù???

What am I missing here?

How is it Oahu? Oahu is the island. 

Am I crazy, or did the proofreader not do his job?

AORTA give you a STAR for this one.  A CLASSIC Monday (no PEAKS necessary, so no rEGRETS).

Thanks, Brian.  I'm COUNTING on seeing you again.  Now I'm hungry.  ASAMIch should fix me right up.
Champion crossword constructer!  Calendar-commencing creativity!
Charming crossword cluing compadre!

Great Monday puzzle! Must admit I didn't notice every clue began with a c until I got to the theme...  Like that experiment where you're so focused on counting basketball passes that you don't notice the gorilla walking by
Can cane-concocted COCA-COLA conserve CLASSIC credentials?

To Andrzej: I so enjoy reading your comments, and knowing your mastery of English, thought you would be interested in the book, "Enough is Enuf. Our Failed Attempts to Make English Easier to Spell," by Gabe Henry. It is full of fascinating fun facts and hilarious. I guess only English- speaking countries have spelling bees for children. A bunch of you crossword solvers will love it, too.

For those of you who are just starting out and are struggling, I'll just let you know that it used to take me forever to do the Monday puzzles and now they are a breeze. And super fun. Hang in there. Your brain will warm up.

What new horror is this?  This was a perfectly reasonable, challenging Saturday puzzle - what is it doing here on a Monday for heaven's sake?  This is a huge editing failure and a let-down to people trying to learn crossword puzzles by taking advantage of the NYT's publicized weekday difficulty progression.  This is the second such one I've noticed in the last year, although this one was even harder and near diabolical.

It wasn't just the upper left as I'd hoped.  There was a marked effort throughout to make this puzzle hard on the silver (even discounting the unfortunate reliance on sports).

If this were Friday or Saturday I would say I enjoyed it.  Because it's a Monday puzzle it makes me angry.  If you're going to stop the courtesy of the difficulty progression, NYT, then please just SAY so, that all bets are off.  I'd probably prefer the randomness. But doing it unannounced is dirty pool.
What is a scad? I am so confused :(

I propose a more specific clue for 69A: "Exclamation made by unobservant solvers who only realize after completing the puzzle that every clue has begun with the same letter." (This refers to a friend's experience, of course.)

I had lAwn before YARD and stop before WAit before WALK ü§£ Finally got there üòÖ 
Congrats, Callahan!
Happy Monday Crosslandia
This was a skosh harder than most Mondays. Crossing INDRA with CAITLIN, and CHALUPAS with OAHU required some backspacing for me.

What Cleverness is this?!
Color me impressed.
Clearly a feat. C's the day!

Fun puzzle, and congrats on the ‚ÄúC‚Äù theme!

I was briefly thrown by the clue to 20 across, which doesn‚Äôt fit the answer‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúCharacteristic of a penetrating mind‚Äù calls for a noun as an answer, but ‚Äúkeen‚Äù is an adjective. ‚ÄúKeenness‚Äù would be the fitting noun. 

‚ÄúPenetrating, as a mind‚Äù would have been the proper formulation of the clue.

Thanks for a great puzzle!
what is phi chi?

PHI Chi... Obviously I entered "tai" there without giving it any more thought. Thankfully CaALUPAS looked really weird and popped at me right away when I checked the grid upon not getting my gold star. In the end I remembered CHALUPAS from an older puzzle - the word is a bit funny for me, as in old Polish cha≈Çupa meant a village house, and it modern Polish it is one of the slang words for "home." Also, RAt may be many things, but certainly not Cardi B's genre ü§™.

Anyway. PHI Chi seems obscure for Monday? It looks like gibberish to me (Greek letters are not commonly used over here, at all, except as symbols in math and physics) so once I got it from crosses upon correcting my error I looked it up. An international medical fraternity you say... So international it only has an entry in English on Wikipedia ü§£

The theme did nothing for me, but it didn't hinder my solve, which is good enough I suppose.

Why is a MACE, specifically, ceremonial? I've seen many more ceremonial swords than maces. It seemed like an odd way to clue that weapon. In Poland for centuries a kind of mace (bu≈Çawa) was the insignia for military officers, pu≈Çkownik (colonel) and hetman (old Polish military rank, roughly equivalent to a top-tier general). However, its purpose wasn't only ceremonial - it was a functional, deadly thing, which happened to also serve as insignia.

Cousins Pyotr and Mikhail review "The Crullers Caramelzov" by Fryo Doughsky.¬†

An international tale of relationships within a rising family:

‚Ä¢ Croquembouche Caramelzov:¬†The family patriarch, puffed up and keeping it together by the thinnest strands.

‚Ä¢ Dmitri Bear Claw Caramelzov:¬†The impulsive nutty son, slashed by a fritter-ing rivalry with his father over dough, and a slick honey named Glazedenka.

‚Ä¢ Ivan Kanelbullar Caramelzov:¬†The intellectual middle bun, knotted up with philosophical extracts about the great baker in the sky.

‚Ä¢ Alexei Fritelle Caramelzov (Zeppole):¬†A devout small donut who tries to leaven troubles between his brothers.

Spoiler/TLDR: Live with kindness! ¬†(ASAMI)
Hooray for The Crullers Caramelzov!

I appreciate that you could have clued SCAD as College in Savannah, but you chose not to do a college abbreviation, Those always irk me, because I‚Äôm not going to memorize hundreds of college abbreviations, as they have no other application in life. 

This puzzle was an incredible feat! Nicely done!
Every single sporting reference (and they usually defeat me) could be filled by crosses. 5 stars to the setter.
Canny commenters commend Callahan‚Äôs clever crossword: ‚ÄúCheers!‚Äù

Probably a good clue to my mental condition. I had trouble with 58A, "City of Honolulu's island." After 43 years of living there and only eight years away, I could not think of any real city besides Honolulu on its island.

I C what you did here, Mr. Callahan. Very clever (and impressively clued!) puzzle. There weren‚Äôt any clues that felt heinously forced, which is a real accomplishment given what you were going for. Bravo!

My observational skills are clearly not particularly KEEN.  I solve on paper, so I can't imagine why I needed the revealer to point out that every single clue begins with a C.  

Maybe it's just a testament to Brian's skill.  Coming up with such natural sounding clues that didn't rouse suspicion is quite a feat.

Okay, now, upon reading the comments just before posting this, I see that @Chris g picked up that the only C's in the across answers are in the themers.  I missed that completely.  Very impressive!

I normally don't comment, but I was absolutely not on a wavelength with the constructor today. My tipping point for this puzzle was the cluing for 63A‚Äîhow exactly does "Cellphone's weather app, e.g." equal WIDGET? A widget is not the same as an app. The app may *have* a widget that can be displayed on the home screen, but this is such a nonsensical clue to me. Seems like I'm the only one taking issue with it, though.

Well that was nice! 
A crossword I could do without revealing or looking up and it wasn't overly easy for me - I got solutions with crossers, including REB and CHALUPAS that I didn't know, and the basketball player. 

Phew! Yesterday I was close to giving up.
Great puzzle! Clues were good, but a few things were missing :) one thing was 43 across, ARETO, this should be ‚ÄòTOO‚Äô to make grammatical sense!
Mondays continue to be not as easy as they used to be (for me anyway) but this was certainly a fun solve, must have been quite a challenge to have all the clues start with C.
Thanks Brian. Much fun!

This puzzle‚Äôs theme was lovely.

                                   -CC

Did more back-tracking than usual for a Monday, but finished a bit more quickly than normal.

Not sure I'm seeing KEEN for "Characteristic of a penetrating mind". Seems the clue calls for a noun?

So there, I was, in my cabin cruiser, off of Cape Cod, snacking on Cap‚Äôn Crunch, candy corn, chocolate chips, cotton candy, and, of course, cold cuts and clam chowder (put together by my celebrity chef), when a California condor flew by, making catcalls.  And I, a career criminal, living in a clown car for too long, I, a Capone career criminal, suddenly wished for a clear conscience.

I wanted to join a chess club, stop making crank calls, get rid of my common cold, join a city council, sing Christmas carols, play clay court tennis without cheating, dance the can-can with a happy heart, watch the Calder Cup or hear the clip clop of horses without gambling, study famous people like Calvin Coolidge and Charlie Chaplin, maybe join a camera crew, use a non-fake credit card, enjoy legitimate chit chat, be caught on Candid Camera doing good things, run cross country, join a chess club, that is, be a force for good.

And I did it!  Vanished from the mob like a cancelled check.  My calling card is now Ex-con Caped Crusader, Captain Contenment.  Case closed.

Really enjoyed this one, and... Wow! The reveal was one of the last things I worked out and then I was just amazed to go back and look over the clues and realize they all started with C's. That's just amazing. And.. to be able to do that and also make this a Monday easy puzzle is just incredible. 

Oh, and as a side note, over time I've come to believe that constructing an early week (easier to solve) puzzle has to be more challenging than constructing the later week puzzles in some ways. There's quite a limitation there. 

I'm done.
Cute! And that's how Sue "C's" it.

The theme was bolstered by a sextet of fresh answers, appearing for the first time in the Times crossword ‚Äì BOOK DEAL, CARD COUNTING, COCA COLA CLASSIC, LET IT REST, CAITLIN CLARK, and CHALUPAS (though this answer has been used in the singular before).  Fresh answers aren‚Äôt automatically good, but these were.

That brought spark.

The all-clues-begin-with-C flew right over my head until I uncovered the reveal. That trick is hard to pull off, as usually, there are clues that feel off or contrived and give it away.  Bravo, Brian! I love being gotten like that.

I was on the wrong track trying to guess the revealer, thinking ‚Äúseize‚Äù would be in it, but my brain relished the effort. And, it turned out to be a lovely revealer, punning on "C's" and alluding to how that letter opens each word of the theme answers.

So, this was more than a Monday blip, it was a day-boost; its charm made my heart smile.  Thank you, Brian!

A good mix of the usual and unusual cluing!
Southwest corner slowed me down. 47D. & 63A. were way outside the box for me.

Off topic question for those who play Strands. 
I just noticed that there's a completion rate stat for the game now, but it tells me I've completed just 21 games with a 100% completion rate. this is very, very off since I've been playing since it was first offered to us. 
Anyone else notice this?
I play on my phone with the Android Games app.
The SW corner was inappropriately natick-y for a Monday. Otherwise, a fun puzzle!
Love it when a Monday puzzle is so engaging. Thank you Mr. C.

Aww nice to see a couple of Peruvian entries on Independence Day! ¬°Felices Fiestas Patrias!

Only last week I was in Ayacucho in the Andes here in Peru, where you can visit the site of the final battle that concreted Peru's (and basically South America's) independence. There's a super monument, great cuisine and lots else to see around the area - very much recommended! Easy 45min flight from Lima.

Very nice puzzle, loved noticing all the "C" clues! Wasn't it mentioned a couple of days ago that there was a puzzle once where all the clues began with "T"? - I think I read about it in the comments on the recent one with black squares shaped like T's, with "Teetotaler" as an answer somewhere.

Nice work, thanks Brian!

"Free of the usual fill"???  Not with 9D in there.  CrossWorld is *tired* of this....9D! 

OPEN SEAS is certainly a phrase I've never heard or read, despite a fondness for naval novels.  I was thinking of something like SEASONAL for the reveal--sly, but more "in the languge."  

There's a wonderful Mexican place called Santo Coyote in Little Rock that we quilters used to visit after our gatherings.  I never tried their CHALUPAS because the Pozole Verde was too delicious to miss.  Hated moving away!  Sigh.  
Off to quilt guild this morning..."Christmas in July"...predicted to be 96 degrees.
Funny story. I had Doh! Instead of Duh.
Cowabunga, that was cool!
Oahu is an island not a city

I had I WON crossing with IM ON which sort of satisfies the cluing even though not what the setter was going for . Took me a while to get it sorted My worse score for a Monday in years. 

Go Liberty!

We win vs We won; I'm in vs I'm on (10D, 22A)

Could have been cleaner.
Per the column...let's start with the obvious: I wasn't paying attention! LOL I had to be told that all the clues started with C. Nice Monday puzzle. Stay cool, fellow puzzlers.
I C what you did there!

Huh, I have a Canon EOS, but it never occurred to me that it was named for the goddess, because it's capitalized. I figured it stood for Electronic Operating System or something like that, because it features a digital autofocus.
Clever, clever, clever.  Congrats!

This took me longer than any Monday puzzle in memory. I learned that the C's in the puzzle's clues and theme answers are called "open", but this is a usage of the word "open" that I am not familiar with.

Small gripe that this is the third day in a row that a puzzle has used ASAMI. We need some fresh filler, friends!

That aside, I enjoyed this puzzle!
Absolutely lovely!

I confess that in my younger days I made a few of what we called "Crank" Calls.

I was certain that was correct for 50D. Especially given the constant Cs.

So it took me way too long to come to AMP for 49A
So so clever. Not easy to fit that much clever in a normal  puzzle size.

For fans of the MIDI: I did not see any over the weekend, but one was posted today. I have not received the Games newsletter that announces it and provides the URL, but I found it by altering the date in the URL, which I highly recommend all Friends of the Midi do on a daily basis. In case you closed a tab or window with the previous MIDI, here is today's URL: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/paid/midi-07-28-25
Very cool! I hunted down the theme clue early and solved it and appreciated every C opener thereafter! So fun!

Heh! 

I just completed today's crossword. 

Those who get upset when the same word appears in two puzzles on the same day are going to need some calming. 

Down, boy!
Surprisingly tricky for a Monday and the C opener for every clue is some mighty fine work
Si, Si, Si!!  Muchas gracias!!

fun puzzle but the C's are not open they're just there - open With 
C's sure - there's gotta be a better reveal clue than 'open' 'starting to see the clue' something like that!
Carefully and creatively concocted. Congrats, creator.
Truly delightful Monday.

This was fun, and I had a little extra challenge in finding my error after I got the Try Again message. Turned out to be IM on instead of IM IN. (Which looks very odd without the apostrophes.) 
Thanks Brian Callahan.
‚ÄúAs am I‚Äù is really having a moment lately.

For @Andrzej and others asking about CHI:
   Just memorize the Greek alphabet.  Only 24 letters and you probably already know many of them. They'll come in handy for Spelling Bee too.
  Fun fact I learned from an older comment:
  OMEGA literally means "big O"
  OMICRON literally means "little O"
I learned them many years ago when I had delusions of someday learning enough  ancient Greek to read Sappho in the original and hear how Homer sounds. Not gonna happen but hey, I can recite the first line of the Iliad!
   And the alphabet will come in handy if you ever visit Greece, which kind of is on MY bucket list.
Had to flyspeck the entire puzzle to figure out that I misspelled EGRET with an I for the second E.  Would have been a near record finish.  GRRRRR.
This puzzle was more than just a nice Money. It had some pizzaz! Thanks Brian!

I haven‚Äôt seen every comment, but was anyone else thrown by the intersection of 10D and 22A?

An A or an O work equally well. I think ‚Äúwe won‚Äú is a better fit than we win.

Not complaining, just observing.

Please forward to tech support.   I would swear my puzzle is perfect, and I can no longer make changes.  I even compared it to the solution, from my phone and from a PC.

But, it doesn't show as complete, and time keeps going up.  There goes a multi year streak.

Please fix.

What a great Monday! My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle- we were amazed when we realized partway through that all the clues started with ‚ÄúC‚Äù! It was delightful. 
We play (nearly) every evening, and always enjoy reading everyone‚Äôs comments after we solve the puzzle! Today is the first time I have made a comment :) 
Despite the sports clues (we do not know sports besides what we have picked up from crosswords) we did pretty well on today‚Äôs puzzle. Abby got ‚ÄúCoca Cola Classic‚Äù almost immediately, which amazed me.
Croquet is played on a lawn, not a yard.

Most of the puzzle was very easy, then the bottom left corner was disproportionately challenging, with more obscure answers, and specific trivia. 

Caitlin Clark isn't particularly solvable if you don't know already, so a bit of a shame to get held up there, since that quadrant held several of the trickier clues requiring specific knowledge.

Would have been nice to have the difficulty spread out rather than densely concentrated.

My favorite used-before clues from last week:

[Medium capacity?]  
[Pop flies?]


ESP
SWAT

@Lewis

I‚Äôm glad to see Noah made the cut.
@Lewis I loved the clue for MIMI! So much in fact that I'm going to refer to my sister as Mimi from here on out. It makes me laugh!

@Lewis

My new pastime- 

Googling ‚Äò‚Äúimages of squirrels splooting‚Äù
(or raccoons, dogs‚Ä¶).

It apparently is my happy place.
Now that you've solved it, I hope you will enjoy the theme(s) I found while solving it. I'm not in a rush. I really enjoy a Monday puzzle I can really enjoy.
Cite: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compadre

I am perplexed that a moderator removed from this thread the exchange of posts discussing that while the the clue and answer do not agree in Spanish they do agree in English. A classic tamale trap. I don't think the OP was offended by anything I wrote, and I certainly was not offended by anything the OP wrote. WHATEVS.

Francis,

What's the rush?  Did you enjoy the open seas?
@Francis agreed, I had multiple naticks in that corner too and blew out to a Tuesday time as a result.  Rest of the puzzle was a nice Monday though!

@HeathieJ

During my cycles through clues for the SW corner, I considered lawn instead of YARD, but it didn't seem to help.

@HeathieJ

I lucked out because I saw the Saint Paul croquet club fanning themselves this evening on summit.  I didn‚Äôt even think of lawn.

@HeathieJ

And I don't get it, at all. It's so weird to not understand a whole sentence of English despite being fluent in the language...
Is it the game of croquet that you don't get? If so, here is a very marvelous clip from a very terribly marvelous movie called, after myself, Heathers https://youtu.be/6ZGGgCD0OGM?si=kqEeevs5__A7s2g8

@HeathieJ

I know croquet. I just don't get the sentence. Is the "fanning" literal? How is "summit" meant there? I'm familiar with all the words that make up Red Carpet's post but I don't get what the sentence means. It feels very strange.

@Andrzej

Summit is an avenue, which if you didn't live in the same area as Red Carpet and I do, you might not know. But it's a big beautiful avenue full of beautiful houses, old timey houses. The Governor of Minnesota's house is on Summit.  It's really quite old and rich and lovely.

I think by fanning themselves, he meant that they were trying to cool themselves down. 

Today was mid-90s Fahrenheit here in this area. So I think they were just trying to cool themselves down and that made him think of the answer. 

‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Andrzej

But also, if you and your wife haven't watched the movie of my namesake, you really should. It's quite terrible.

@HeathieJ

But I really am quite nicer then the Heathers portrayed in that movie. 

Or so I'd like you to believe. 

Uyahahah.. .

@Andrzej
And the same when English is your first language! Not for this clue, but it happens.

@HeathieJ

The acting in that clip was so cringey I just couldn't take it :D :D

I closed the video after 10 seconds :D

(and this is coming from a guy who loved Buffy the Vampire Slayer :D)

@Jane Wheelaghan Around these parts, the land surrounding one's house is their yard. This may be the front yard, the back yard, the side yard, or, you have a bent towards Walt Whitman, the dooryard. https://allpoetry.com/When-Lilacs-Last-in-the-Dooryard-Bloom'd And generally, it's covered with lawn, trees and shrubs. A garden, on the other hand, may be part of the yard, and would consist of specific types of flowers and decorations (rose garden, Japanese garden, Zen garden) or, for those leaning toward home agriculture, vegetables.

@Steve L
Thanks. I've just found out that yard and garden have the same Germanic root, meaning 'enclosure, fenced area'. I love the history of words!
Let's see what these folks have to say about it... https://www.britannica.com/topic/Indra

Yes, it does go on to say that ... about "later Hinduism."
I trust you read the earlier part about earlier Hinduism. 
The clue doesn't specify a period.

Haha?
@Barry Ancona that doesn‚Äôt make Indra the chief Hindu god though, not as Hinduism is currently practiced.

@SIJ
1. Clues and answers are not dictionary or encyclopedia entries, they are hints.
2. Too many words in a clue (like adding "in ancient times") make the clue dull.
3. The clue needed to start with a C. Maybe there were better Cs. 

The clue certainly didn't hold me back, because I didn't know the answer anyway. Sometimes a little knowledge does hold me back, for example 1D. I'm thinking well MACE fits, but isn't that more of an offensive weapon and not ceremonial? A little overthinking there!

@SIJ

My guess is that INDRA was gotten by nearly everyone, including BA, through the crosses, which were kind. Yes, the dictionary/encyclopedia entries provide support for the clue, but I don't think it is a slam dunk for non-Hindi people. I wonder how it relates to Indira Ghandi, the former PM of India.

@Mike

Deep thought.  Very sailent.  Your wisdom is surfacing‚Äîsalty but not at all blue.

Mike,

Shipshape post.

(Stay on an even keel.)
I think these puns manifest an unmoored psyche, but then it‚Äôs knot for me to judge.

Tim,

Perhaps it will be clearer if I rephrase the clue.
On what island is the city of Honolulu?

@Tim

I thought it was worded oddly, too. But: Honolulu is a city. Therefore, "Honolulu's island" is OAHU.

@Tim

That caught me at first too but Oahu is the island of the city that is Honolulu.

Honolulu's island is Oahu.

If you twist the words around a couple times, it's more apparent.

Hope this helps!

Liz,

The clue is "worded oddly" to start with a C 
like every other clue in the puzzle.
@Barry Ancona OMG! I see. Thank you. And my apologies to the proofreader. üôèüòÇ

@Steve L

As a researcher of public administration I find that so weird! The whole purpose of local government is to design its units so that they are small enough for their authorities to be close to the issues to be solved, with all their diversity. Poland's local government functions on 3 tiers: communes, counties and provinces (gminy, powiaty, wojew√≥dztwa). The largest cities combine the status of commune and county. However, for the most local issues to be solved, they are subdivided into districts (effectively, an additional tier of local government below the commune) which bring local governance closer to the people. Also, these commune/county cities are usually surrounded by the donut of another county, rural, which reflects the need for different governance of rural and urban areas.
@Tim ‚ÄòCity of Honolulu‚Äô ‚Ä¶. as in ‚ÄòCity of New York‚Äô or ‚ÄòCity of Cincinnati‚Äô.

@CB
We who solve on the website never see the complete clue list -- each clue comes up one by one as you move from one answer to the next -- so we had no chance to see the array of Cs. Rats!

@SBK

I think you mean website viewed on a phone. Website on my laptop clearly shows all the C's.

@Canoe-er
Si si!

@Marcia Fidler

Thanks for the tip. That may be a bit niche for me though, and I also often balk at the sort of humor American authors seem to favor when writing facetiously about facts. I'll add the book to my Kindle wishlist and try a sample later to make up my mind.

Polish doesn't have spelling bees. However, one of our linguistic staples is the dyktando - the word may look familiar, because it is related to your "dictating", as in reading out loud.

During a dyktando, a person reads a text full of complex, unusual words and punctuation (where to put a comma is much more complicated in Polish than in English), and participants attempt to write it down.

Dyktando is one of the basic components of Polish language classes in primary school, but there are also advanced dyktanda (that's the plural of dyktando) for adults, prepared by best Polish linguists, like Jerzy Bralczyk. They are so fiendishly difficult I would never be able to complete one without errors, even though my Polish is basically perfect. The thing is, an adult dyktando is a bit like a Saturday puzzle at the NYT: tricky on purpose, and dipping heavily into the repository of the language's most obscure words.

@Andrzej

Sounds fascinating.  Are these televised?

Your comment on the use of commas being more difficult in Polish than English must startle a lot of English users.  Because one of the most common complaints about grammar is figuring out when to use a comma.

I almost never worry about the rules for commas.  The best advice I ever got was this:  if you were saying something and it was a good place for a pause in the pace, that's a place for a comma.

I used that in the last sentence of the proceeding paragraph.  I don't know for sure that it's right, but I've never had anyone complain about my commas.

@Francis I have no graps of the vocabulary to describe the role of the comma in Polish. The thing is, english lacks some of the grammar and syntax constructs that necessitate the use of a comma in Polish, so I can talk about this stuff in Polish only. Also, another major feaure of Polish is whether to write down negation, such as "nie" ("no") as a separate word or as part of another. For example, "unwittingly" in Polish is "niechcƒÖcy" (nie, no + chcƒÖcy, willing). However, if I try to convey the same thing not with an adverb with with a verb-based phrase, it looks different: "nie chcƒÖc" (not willing). As to your question if dyktanda are televised - I have no idea. I mean, I've always been a geek and a nerd, but not to the extent that I'd watch a dyktando on TV, or even think about it :D A YT search seems to imply some dyktanda have been televised or streamed: https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=og%C3%B3lnopolskie+dyktando (No, I have not clicked any of the videos)

@Francis This reddit thread is actually quite informative, and it captures the main differences between the use of commas in English and Polish: https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpolish/comments/1butsfn/commas/ BTW. I love the Oxford comma in English. It is such an elegant thing, and it makes a lot of sense. I tried to introduce it into Polish in my academic and scholarly writing, but editors always deleted it, and I gave up :( "Kocham rodzic√≥w, HeathieJ i Francisa" ("I love my parents, HeathieJ and Francis") is the only kosher way to write that sentence down in Polish: no "I love my parents, HeathieJ, and Francis" for us :(. To avoid misunderstandings, I would have to style the sentence differently, for example: "Kocham rodzic√≥w, a tak≈ºe HeathieJ i Francisa" ("I love my parents, as well as HeathieJ and Francis").

@Andrzej

Thanks!  

I don't think I've ever intentionally not used an Oxford comma.

To me it's a matter of symmetry, almost mathematical (üòÄ):  why would one purposely *not* treat the penultimate and ultimate member of a series the same as every member of the series before it?

@Francis
I don't know not, but I was taught the alternative, and just stuck with it. Hard to deny 60+ years of habit.

@Jane Wheelaghan Thanks. Maybe it's just not a Polish thing. Other than royal scepters, I can't think of any ceremonial objects akin to maces over here. Or maybe I can? The speakers open the sessions of both chambers of our Parliament knocking their wooden staffs on the floor, and they look vaguely mace-like. The thing is called "laska" in Polish, so literally a cane. Wikipedia only describes it in Polish, with pictures: https://pl.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laska_marsza%C5%82kowska_(Polska) The article says historically the "laska" would have been carried before the king when he attended parlament, so there clearly is some relation to the ceremonial maces you describe. @Barry Ancona

Dictionary definition notwithstanding, a widget is a feature of an app, not an app as such itself - much like an alarm feature on a regular clock is not a clock itself.
It very well may be, and that is distracting you from the meaning of WIDGET that dates from 1924...

@Barry Ancona

But the meaning from 1924 is "gadget". The clue was not about gadgets, it was about apps. You can't have a widget without a corresponding app on your phone, and many apps come without widgets. Clearly, a widget is not an app but an app's feature.
An app can be considered a gadget.

@E. This completely threw me, too. It was clearly not WIDGET for exactly the reason you say, so I kept trying to re-do the SW corner. It's unfortunate that a general lay usage of the term overlaps with something that will be defined more precisely in developer documentation, but it's not an unheard of thing to happen. Here's to better luck for us tomorrow!

@Anthony
It's the kind of thing I get via the crosses.  Then after I finish the puzzle, I ask DHubby to explain what is meant by any technology-related entry/clue.  (On the other hand, he can't tell one plant/tree from another--that's my department.)

@E.
The thing I see on my cell phone that gets me to the weather app on my cell phone is a widget.

It's a little larger than the usual app icon because it also shows me the current temperature and where I am.

Most apps just have an icon.  But some, with constantly changing info -- like clock and weather -- have a larger 'icon' called a widget.

If you go into the screen-editing mode on your phone, you will have a choice to add Widgets.  I could also have widgets for my calendar that would show upcoming appointments, or for my email that would show newest 3 email subjects.

At least this is the way it works for Android.  I think iOS is similar.
